head.title: Bush and Gore, on the Battleground of Ideas; Social Security

hedline.hl1: Bush and Gore, on the Battleground of Ideas; Social Security

abstract.p: Andrew G Biggs letter dispputes Paul Krugman's stand in Sept 6 column that George W Bush's Social Security plan would inevitably cut benefits0

block.p: Paul Krugman (column, Sept. 6) asserts that George W. Bush's Social Security plan would inevitably cut benefits, since it ''will reduce the inflow of money into the Social Security system by $1.3 trillion over the next decade.'' He then asks ''if contributions are down, and benefits are not, where does the money come from?'' The answer is simple: from payroll tax surpluses.

Paul Krugman (column, Sept. 6) asserts that George W. Bush's Social Security plan would inevitably cut benefits, since it ''will reduce the inflow of money into the Social Security system by $1.3 trillion over the next decade.'' He then asks ''if contributions are down, and benefits are not, where does the money come from?'' The answer is simple: from payroll tax surpluses.

According to Social Security's trustees, from 2000 to 2009 the program will run a cash surplus of $928 billion, plus $1.2 trillion in interest to the trust fund. Personal retirement accounts financed with 2 percent of the wages would cost $988 billion if all workers took part.
Personal accounts are affordable and, unlike the current system, would truly save today's payroll tax surpluses to pay benefits in the future.
The writer is a Social Security analyst at the Cato Institute.
